summary: Improve Ruby scheduler memory efficiency by replacing array-based ready fiber list with a proper queue data structure to avoid repeated shift/append operations.
userImpact: Users may experience unnecessary memory pressure and garbage collection overhead due to inefficient array operations in the fiber scheduler.
rootCause: Using array with repeated shift and append operations creates unnecessary memory churn instead of using a proper queue data structure.
proposedFix: Replace array-based ready fiber list with a queue data structure using non-blocking pop operations.
resolutionDetails: Author noted that while queue would be cleaner, the current implementation completely drains the array anyway, making the optimization not beneficial in practice.
keyQuote: Note, queue is a bit blocked on how it is used with our fiber scheduler. The way we completely drain this array means it's actually not a big deal here.
